The question of who decides what is best for society as a whole is a complex one, and there is no simple answer. In a democratic system, elected officials are elected by the people to represent their interests and make decisions on their behalf. However, the influence of special interest groups, including corporations, can sometimes impact the decisions made by elected officials, leading to outcomes that may not serve the best interests of society as a whole.

This is why it's important for citizens to be engaged in the political process and to hold their elected officials accountable. By participating in elections, contacting their representatives, and engaging in advocacy and activism, citizens can help to ensure that the decisions made by elected officials reflect the will of the people and serve the greater good.

With regards to climate protection, it is a complex and challenging issue that requires the cooperation and commitment of governments, corporations, and individuals alike. While the influence of special interest groups can sometimes pose obstacles to meaningful action on climate change, there are also many examples of successful policy initiatives and corporate practices that prioritize sustainability and environmental protection.

Ultimately, it is up to all of us to take responsibility for ensuring that our elected officials are making decisions that serve the best interests of society and the planet. This can include supporting candidates and policies that prioritize climate action, engaging in activism and advocacy efforts, and making personal choices that align with our values and priorities.
